But perhaps this is a standard question where the options are common disadvantages. Let me think. Longitudinal studies have several disadvantages. Common ones include high cost, time-consuming, participant attrition (people dropping out over time), potential for cohort effects (changes due to being part of a particular generation rather than age), and possible changes in the environment that affect results. 

If the options were something like: 
I. High cost and time
II. Participant attrition
III. Cohort effects

Then the answer would depend on which of these are considered disadvantages. All three are commonly cited disadvantages. Alternatively, if the options were I and II, or others.
